My dear wife of my heart  
Porto Alegre, December 15, 1835.

I have already received two of yours, and from the contentment they both produced in me, you can judge by the sensations you feel upon receiving mine. I had been very distressed until just a few days ago, thinking that well-directed intrigues had produced distrust among ours; however, seeing the opposite, that we are firmly progressing in the good of our Province, pleasure has been revived in my heart. Now I live contentedly, and the girls do not leave me with distress; poor things, who waste their time, for I pay no attention to them and, consequently, all say that there is no girl more fortunate than you, that I am the example of the married, and by this I make the state desirable. And what do you say? See how much my behavior is worth and how happy you are possessing a husband who is young, handsome, well-made, and faithful. Where does one find so many things together? Indeed, in this century it is a phenomenon, a marvel, etc., etc.

Hugs to our children, regards to all our kin, and farewell until the 23rd of this month, God willing; keep something for me.  
Your husband of the heart, Almeida.

To Mrs. Bernardina Barcelos de Almeida. Pelotas.
